PHC230H1-S-20209.courseDescription: An introduction to the key concepts in the design, manufacture, and use of efficatious dosage forms. The course covers the characteristics of different delivery routes.
PHC230H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded.  Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

PHC300H1-F-20209.courseDescription: Structural and mechanistic determinants of drug action at the molecular level. Topics include the physicalchemical properties of drugs per se as they relate to therapeutic intervention and the biophysical and biochemical properties of enzymes and nucleic acids that underlie and are affected by their interactions with drugs.
PHC300H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

PHC301H1-S-20209.courseDescription: Structural and mechanistic determinants of drug action via macromolecules that effect cellular signalling. Neurohumoral receptors and other signalling proteins are grouped according to their structure and mechanism of action. Native properties and their modulation by drugs are discussed in the context of basic principles of molecular pharmacology.
PHC301H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: If normal classes have not resumed by January of 2021, lectures and tutorials will be delivered online in a synchronous manner. The schedule will be published in due course.  It is expected that the platform will be Blackboard Collaborate, which can be accessed via Quercus.  Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.
PHC301H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

PHC320H1-S-20209.courseDescription: Modern discovery and synthesis of antibiotics, antineoplastics, antiviral and other therapeutic agents.
PHC320H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: If conditions allow, in-person classes will be planned. Otherwise, Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.
PHC320H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

PHC330H1-F-20209.courseDescription: This course presents a detailed examination of the material properties of pharmaceuticals and the role of cellular processes in delivery of a drug to its site of action.
PHC330H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded.

Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

PHC331H1-S-20209.courseTitle: Establishing the Bioequivalence of Pharmaceutical Products
PHC331H1-S-20209.courseDescription: Introduction to human clinical trial design for the demonstration of pharmaceutical bioequivalence of drug products. Students will learn the principles underlying the regulations and methods employed in bioequivalence studies.
PHC331H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures and oral presentations will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

PHC340Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: The scientific basis and practical techniques relevant to modern pharmaceutical development. This course is restricted to Pharmaceutical Chemistry Specialist program students.
PHC340Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions:
Please note that the times for this course are different in Fall and Winter, as follows -- 

Fall Term: 

  • Mondays 3:00 to 4:00 p.m. (lecture)
  • Thursdays 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. in PB 860 (lab)

Winter Term: 

  • Tuesdays 11:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. (lecture)
  • Thursdays 1:00 to 5:00 p.m. in PB 860 (lab).
PHC340Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Labs will be delivered in-person with social distancing for the Fall and Winter semester. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

PHC420H1-S-20209.courseTitle: Application of Medicinal Chemistry to Pharmacology
PHC420H1-S-20209.courseDescription: This course shows students the links between basic science and the drugs used therapeutically to treat clinical problems. This course is restricted to Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program students.
PHC420H1-S-20209.prerequisite: PHC301H1, PHC320H1, and enrolled as a Year 4 student in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.
PHC420H1-S-20209.webTimetableInstructions: There will be an introductory online session (either online or in-person depending on what circumstances allow), to explain the format of the course. The core of the course is made up of a series of ungraded online “quizzes” with feedback.  There will be an oral online Socratic examination.
PHC420H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions:
All lectures will be pre-recorded and delivered online asynchronously. Students will require to access the recorded lectures through a web browser.

At this time, the University has not made a final decision about course delivery for the Winter 2021 term. The Faculty of Arts & Science will be updating Winter term course delivery information based on public health guidelines.

PHC421H1-S-20209.courseDescription: This course will consider many of the topics presented in the first half in much greater detail including a rigorous examination of the interpretation of experimental data. This course is intended for students whose research or interest is in the thermodynamics of biological molecules. This course is restricted to Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program students.
PHC421H1-S-20209.prerequisite: Enrolled as a Year 4 student in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.
PHC421H1-S-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

LEC-0101.meetingStatusNotes: January 19, 2021:  Delivery Method Changed to Online-Synchronous

PHC435H1-F-20209.courseDescription: Application and development of devices for the purpose of collecting and analyzing experimental data in pharmaceutical development and manufacture.
PHC435H1-F-20209.prerequisite: BCH210H1, CHM247H1/CHM249H1, (MAT135H1, MAT136H1)/MAT137Y1, PHC340Y1 and enrolled as a Year 4 student in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.
PHC435H1-F-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Lectures and lab activities will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser. Students will be required to purchase an electronics kit, to participate in hands-on activities during lectures.
PHC435H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions: Lectures and lab activities will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded. Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

PHC470H1-F-20209.courseDescription: This course is designed for students who are interested in the critical analysis of global health policy and the interrelationship between global and domestic policy issues. The course will introduce students generally to the basic concepts and issues in global health with a particular focus on pharmaceutical policy. We will address key issues in health and discuss core institutional and transnational actors, how governments in different jurisdictions manage public health responsibilities, the tension between economic imperatives and health objectives, global obligations, and pressure from special interest groups. More narrowly, we will analyse a breadth of complex policies questions. Examples include: the research and development global divide, policial issues influences on pharmaceutical policy, how global commitments, such as membership in the World Trade Organization, conflict with or correspond to domestic policy directions and national sovereignty. Guest speakers will lead some sessions. This course will consist of lectures, guest discuttions, case studies and student-led presentations. This is restricted to students in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.
PHC470H1-F-20209.prerequisite: Enrolled as a Year 4 student in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.
PHC470H1-F-20209.deliveryInstructions:
Lectures and tutorials will be delivered online per the meeting schedule and recorded.

Students will require the ability to use videoconferencing software through a web browser.

PHC489Y1-Y-20209.courseDescription: This course will provide research experience under the supervision of a Departmental staff member. The goal is to deepen the student’s understanding of the scientific basis and practical techniques relevant to modern pharmaceutical development. This course is restricted to Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
PHC489Y1-Y-20209.prerequisite: Permission from the Course Coordinator and enrolled as a Year 4 student in the Pharmaceutical Chemistry specialist program.
PHC489Y1-Y-20209.webTimetableInstructions: Research projects will be in-person or online, depending on what is agreed upon between the supervisor and the student. Project interviews will be performed synchronously online or in-person, depending on what is agreed upon between the supervisor and the student. Presentation elements of research projects may be administered either synchronously online, in-person, or both depending on what circumstances allow for in the Winter term.
PHC489Y1-Y-20209.deliveryInstructions: Research projects will be in-person or online, depending on what is agreed upon between the supervisor and the student. Mid-course evaluations will be performed synchronously online or in-person, depending on what is agreed upon between the supervisor and the student. Presentation elements of research projects may be administered either synchronously online, in-person, or both depending on what circumstances allow for in the Winter term.
